title-group.article-title: Two-year outcomes of Elektra prosthesis for trapeziometacarpal osteoarthritis: a longitudinal cohort study

contrib-group.aff: Hand Surgery Unit, Orthopaedic Surgery Department of ‘San Cecilio’ University Hospital, Granada, Spain
Hand Surgery Unit, Orthopaedic Surgery Department of ‘San Juan de Diós’ Hospital, Seville, Spain
Hand Surgery Unit, Orthopaedic Surgery Department of ‘Torrecardenas’ Hospital, Almeria, Spain

author-notes.corresp: Pedro Hernández-Cortes, Rector Marín Ocete, 10, Granada 18014, Spain Email: hdezcp@hotmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The British Society for Surgery of the Hand 2011
permissions.copyright-holder: The British Society for Surgery of the Hand

abstract.p: The aim of this study was to evaluate clinical and radiographic outcomes of Elektra® trapeziometacarpal prostheses after 2 years. We present a longitudinal cohort study of 19 prostheses for the treatment of Eaton stage II and III osteoarthritis (mean follow-up of 29 months). QuickDASH score, pinch strength and mobility were determined, and radiographs were analysed. Isotope scans were taken in patients with persistent pain or suspected loosening. Although the QuickDASH score was 69 before and 38 after surgery, nine patients had pain at the trapeziometacarpal joint with radiographic osteolysis around the trapezium component and a positive bone scan uptake at subsequent follow-up. The implant was revised in three of these nine patients and another patient underwent surgery for periprosthetic fracture. Only ten of the 19 implants showed no sign of failure. Most problems derived from the trapezium cup. Because of these poor outcomes after only 2 years, we cannot recommend this implant.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Trapeziectomy with ligament reconstruction and tendon interposition is widely used to treat thumb osteoarthritis (Ghavami and Oishi, 2006), but a systematic review concluded that there was insufficient evidence to be conclusive about the best treatment (Wajon et al., 2009). As is the case in other joints, prostheses have been developed, of which the most popular is the De la Caffinière prosthesis (Boeckstyns et al., 1989; Chakrabarti et al., 1997; Comtet and Rumelhart, 2001; Cooney et al., 1987; De la Caffinière, 1973; 2001; De la Caffinière and Aucuturier, 1979; De Smet et al., 2004), although other cemented (Braun, 1982; Ferrari and Steffee, 1986; Linscheid and Dobyns, 1979) and cementless (Comtet, 2000; Ledoux, 1994) prostheses have been reported (Wachtl et al., 1998).

Ball-and-socket implants have shown encouraging results in numerous studies. Sondergaard et al. (1991) reported implant survival of 82% at 9 years, Chakrabarti et al. (1997) published the results of 93 de la Caffinière basal joint replacements with a survival rate of 89% at 16 years and Badia and Sambandan (2006) also obtained excellent outcomes using Braun–Cutter arthroplasty, with no aseptic loosening. Ulrich-Vinther et al. (2008) found that patients with joint prostheses experienced a more rapid and comfortable recovery and showed greater strength and range of movement at 1 year in comparison to patients treated with tendon interposition arthroplasty.

Initial reports on the treatment of osteoarthrosis of the trapeziometacarpal joint with the Elektra® prosthesis were controversial. Regnard (2006) published good outcomes in a series of 100 patients followed up for a mean of 54 months, but Hansen and Snerum (2008) reported mediocre results with the same implant.

Our study was prompted by the need for further analysis of a different series of patients with trapeziometacarpal osteoarthritis treated with the Elektra® prosthesis. The objective was to evaluate the clinical and radiographic outcomes of Elektra® trapeziometacarpal prostheses after 2 years.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: This longitudinal cohort study comprised patients with stage II or III (Eaton and Glickel, 1987) trapeziometacarpal osteoarthritis that conservative treatment had failed to resolve and who underwent Elektra® trapeziometacarpal arthroplasty between February 2007 and February 2008. Exclusion criteria were the presence of an upper limb lesion other than trapeziometacarpal osteoarthritis and radiographic findings of degenerative changes of the scapho-trapezium-trapezoid joint.

Nineteen hands (13 right and dominant hands) were operated in nineteen patients with Eaton trapeziometacarpal osteoarthritis stage II (8 cases) or III (11 cases). All were female, with a mean age of 57 (range 45–76) years and mean follow-up of 29 (range 24–36) months.

sec.title: Prosthesis design
sec.p: We used the Elektra (Elektra®, Fixano, Péronnas, France) unconstrained ‘ball-and-socket’ trapeziometacarpal prosthesis for noncemented fixation. The metacarpal implant is a titanium hydroxyapatite-coated stem available in four sizes. The trapezium component is a chrome–cobalt cone-shaped steel cup with threaded hydroxyapatite surface, available in only one size. The chrome–cobalt steel head and neck are modular and available in four sizes.

sec.title: Surgical technique
sec.p: A single dose of 2 g cephazolin was administered to all patients preoperatively. All were operated under regional anaesthesia. All prostheses were implanted by means of an ‘S’-shaped dorsoradial approach using a tourniquet. After identifying and protecting superficial branches of the radial nerve, trapeziometacarpal capsulotomy was carried out between the abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons. Subperiosteal exposure of the base of the metacarpal and trapezium was followed by osteotomy of the metacarpal joint surface with an oscillating saw. The metacarpal was reamed to the exact size, and the stem was press-fit inserted. The trapezium joint surface was not resected, apart from osteophytes, but was drilled with cannulated instruments followed by implantation of the screw cup. A distraction forceps was used to calculate the length of the head-and-neck component. After testing the tension, stability and mobility with a trial component, this was replaced with the definitive implant. The capsule was reconstructed with resorbable interrupted sutures, and the skin was closed with 4/0 monofilament suture. Postoperatively, wrist and thumb were radiographically examined and then immobilized in a splint for 3 weeks (Figure 1). All patients were discharged at 12 hours after surgery.

caption.p: A. Trapeziometacarpal osteoarthritis Eaton stage III. B. Treated with Elektra trapeziometacarpal prosthesis.

sec.p: After 3 weeks, the splint was removed and replaced with a soft elastic bandage. Patients were then referred to the Department of Rehabilitation for re-education of thumb opposition and abduction.

sec.title: Instruments and measures
sec.p: The clinical assessment was carried out independently by two of the authors (M.J.R.-M., R.G.-S.), who were blinded to the surgical procedure and radiographic findings. The QuickDASH score (Beaton et al., 2005) was determined for each patient. It is based on an 11-item questionnaire (completion of ≥10 responses is essential) and calculated by dividing the sum of responses by the number of completed responses, subtracting 1 and then dividing by 25; the score ranges from score 0 = normal hand function to 100 = severe hand/upper extremity impairment. A visual analogue scale was used to assess pain (0 = no pain to 10 = worst pain imaginable). Pinch strength was measured with a custom-designed pinch device and mobility was assessed by applying the Kapandji score (Kapandji, 1986). All of the above determinations, along with clinical and radiographic examinations, were performed preoperatively and at the final follow-up (minimum 2 years), which was immediately before revision surgery in patients requiring this treatment. Isotope scans were taken in patients with persistent pain or suspected loosening. Radiographic analysis was independently performed by two of the authors (M.A.T.-R., J.T.-U.), who were blinded to the clinical assessment. Radiographic data included (a) positional variables: trapezial cup position, angle formed by trapezium and cup axis, distance from the top of the trapezial component to the scaphoid–trapezium joint; and (b) loosening variables: presence of radiolucent lines, osteolysis and component subsidence. A prosthesis was categorized as loose if it was confirmed at revision surgery, or if there was persistent pain with radiographic changes of osteolysis, component subsidence or migration and a positive technetium isotope scan.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Preoperative and postoperative values of the study variables were compared by applying the paired Student’s t-test. The effect size (ES) (mean of the change pre - post/standard deviation [SD] at baseline or pre-treatment) and standardized response mean (SRM) (mean of the change pre - post/SD of the change) were also calculated. Multivariate analyses were used to evaluate the relationship between radiographic and loosening variables. A value of p < 0.05 was considered significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The mean QuickDASH Score was 69 before surgery and 38 at the final follow-up (Student’s t-test; p < 0.001). Mean visual analogue pain score was 8.4 before surgery and 4.6 at the 2-year follow-up (p < 0.001). Seven patients had a score ≥5 points at the follow-up, and four showed the same score as before the operation. The mean pinch strength at follow-up was 68% of the preoperative value. Four patients had dysaesthesia of the superficial branch of the radial nerve. One patient had severe algodystrophy and secondary stiffness of the hand with first web contracture (Table 1). There were no intraoperative complications or perioperative infections, and no dislocations were observed at the follow-up.

fn.p: Pinch strength measured with a custom-designed pinch device measuring in pounds (lb) (preoperative versus postoperative value); VAS: visual analogue score (0 = no pain to 10 = worst pain imaginable); Kapandji: Kapandji thumb opposition score; QuickDASH score (0 points = normal hand function to 100 points = severe hand/upper extremity problems); SRB: superficial radial branch; TAL: trapezial aseptic loosening; MTS: metacarpal stem; SRD: sympathetic reflex dystrophy; ES: effect size; SRM: standardized response mean.

sec.p: Nine patients had trapezial pain with radiographic osteolysis and positive isotope scan (Figure 2); three of these underwent surgical revision of the prosthesis, one had repeat surgery for periprosthetic fracture and another showed osteolysis around both metacarpal and trapezial components (Figure 3).

caption.p: A. Painful Elektra trapeziometacarpal prosthesis at 10 months after implantation. B. Positive isotope scan suggesting trapezial loosening. C. Peritrapezial osteolysis (black arrow). D. Threaded cup migration.
A. Elektra trapeziometacarpal prosthesis. B. At 2 years after implantation, metacarpal and trapezial osteolysis (black arrows).

sec.p: The revision procedure was resection arthroplasty and abductor pollicis longus tenoplasty (Sigfusson and Lundborg, 1991) (Figure 4). Only 10 implants showed no signs of failure.

caption.p: A. Elektra trapeziometacarpal prosthesis revised by trapeziectomy and tenoplasty with abductor pollicis longus strip (APL) as described by Lundborg and Sigfusson, because the metacarpal stem was impossible to remove. B. Diagram of the tenoplasty, with no need for bone tunnels (FCR: flexor carpi radialis).

sec.p: The multivariate analysis showed that no radiographic positional parameters were associated with the presence of radiolucent lines, osteolysis, or component subsidence (Table 2).

caption.p: Main radiographic values for each patient

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although the study design, sample size, and follow-up were inadequate to draw definitive conclusions, the results obtained were sufficiently alarming for us to discontinue using this implant at our centre. All of the nine patients with peritrapezial cup osteolysis at 2 years reported pain in the trapezium area from the early postoperative period and had a positive isotopic scan for the trapezial component (not the metacarpal stem) at 1 year after operation. Progressive osteolysis leading to gross migration was observed in three patients and pathological trapezium fracture in another (all required revision). The early onset of these symptoms suggests that osseointegration failure may have played a greater role than aseptic loosening. A mean DASH score improvement was observed after the final evaluation, because the symptoms were less severe at the onset of radiographic loosening and became worse with the passage of time. The high failure rate cannot be related to the learning curve of our team, which has considerable experience of fitting the Arpe® (Biomet Merck) prosthesis (Isselin, 2001).

Regnard (2006) published the first series of patients treated with the Elektra® prosthesis, obtaining good outcomes in 83 out of 100 patients followed up for a mean of 54 months and reporting seven dislocations, five of which were due to severe trauma; the most frequent complication was non-osseointegration of the trapezial part of the prosthesis, observed in 15 cases (15%).

In contrast, Hansen and Snerum (2008) reported mediocre results in their follow-up study of 16 patients (mean of 35 months); six of their patients required revision, including four with aseptic loosening of the screw cup, migration and progressive pain. One of the eleven remaining patients showed cup migration and loosening at the radiological follow-up, therefore only ten of 16 implants continued to function properly.

Most of the problems in our patients derived from the trapezium cup, which is threaded in this system. In hip replacement surgery, first-generation threaded cups, which were commonly treated with smooth surfaces, showed unacceptably high medium-term failure rates. In fact, some authors opposed the use of smooth, threaded acetabular components because they do not provide satisfactory long-term fixation (Aldinger et al., 2004). However, a radiographic follow-up study (Trapotsis et al., 2009) found that second-generation hydroxyapatite-coated threaded acetabular cups remained stable in all hip replacement patients after a mean follow-up of 10.2 years, with bone ingrowth fixation and no significant relevant cup migration or osteolytic areas. The cumulative survival rate of the implants was 97%, supporting the use of this second-generation system.

Various geometries have been explored in attempts to optimize the primary fixation of the cup of the Arpe® trapeziometacarpal prosthesis, including cups designed with slots, blades, or crowns (Bruyère Garnier, 2001). However, we could find no biomechanical study on trapeziometacarpal prostheses with threaded components. Other variables warranting investigation include surface friction and head volume.

There was only one case of metacarpal bone resorption in our series (Figure 2). Koebke (1993) reported that prosthesis implantation reduces bending stress, leading to bony resorption (stress shielding). This phenomenon explains the radiolucent lines at the interface of the metacarpal component. However, the morphology of the metacarpal osteolysis and the simultaneous trapezial involvement suggest a foreign body reaction to debris in the present case.

The dorsal approach was associated with a high rate of dysaesthesia of the superficial branch of the radial nerve, and our team now prefers the Wagner approach (Wagner, 1950) in trapeziometacarpal arthroplasty. The incision is made along the dorsal radial aspect of the first metacarpal bone and curved along the flexion crease of the wrist. The thenar muscles are stripped away subperiosteally and the capsule incised, exposing the trapeziometacarpal joint.

Removal of the hydroxyapatite metacarpal stem poses a major challenge in revision surgery, and an approach that avoids metacarpal tunnels is recommended, such as the Sigfusson and Lundborg (1991) technique used in the present patients.

Good outcomes were reported by authors (Apard and Saint-Cast, 2007) who rescued failed arthroplasties using trapeziectomy and interposition of the palmaris longus tendon according to the technique of Jones (1990) or abductor pollicis longus tendon interposition arthroplasty (Ulrich-Vinther et al., 2008) and leaving the metacarpal stem in place, although pinch strength values were low.

Further studies are needed to corroborate the excellent outcomes published by Regnard (2006). Based on our experience, we can no longer recommend this joint replacement technique and advocate a close follow-up of patients fitted with this implant.

ack.p: The authors are grateful to Richard Davies for editorial assistance and Dr Francisco del Piñal for scientific counselling.

sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.

sec.p: None declared.
